children.name: mountains x
children.definition: mountainsused as part of a name for a group of mountains: vùng núi
examples: the blue ridge mountains of virginia

children.name: mountain a2
children.definition: mountain a very high hill : núi
examples: the highest mountain in austria
highthese mountains are much higher than any in europe.
rugged mountains(= rough and uneven )the spectacular scenery of rugged mountains
a snow-capped mountain(= with snow on the top )beautiful views of snow-capped mountains
a distant mountain(= far away )the sun was setting over the distant mountains.
a great mountain(= a high, impressive mountain )here, great mountains are all around.
a sacred mountain(= considered holy )mount fuji is a sacred mountain.
go/walk up a mountain(alsoascend a mountainformal)carrie and albert went up the mountain, neither of them speaking as they climbed.
climb a mountain(= walk and/or climb to the top of a mountain )hillary had climbed all the big mountains in new zealand.
go/walk down a mountainshe lost her way as she went down the mountain.
cross the mountainswe crossed the mountains between spain and france.
mountains rise(= go high into the sky )the mountains rise above the plains.
moutains soar/towerliterary(= go very high into the sky )the distant mountains soar abruptly towards the sky.
a mountain range/chain(= a number of mountains in a line )the alps are the largest mountain range in europe.
a mountain topuntil the end of june you may find snow on the mountain tops.
a mountain peak(= the top of a mountain )clouds hid the mountain peaks.
a mountain slope(= the sides of a mountain )snow lay on the steep mountain slopes.
a mountain pass(= a path or road between mountains )their journey took them through river valleys and over mountain passes.
a mountain streamthe water was as clear and cold as a mountain stream.
mountain aira walk in the clear mountain air
mountain rescue(= people who help people who are in difficulty on a mountain )mountain rescue teams were called out to search for the missing climbers.
the top of a mountain(alsothe summit of a mountainformal)we climbed to the top of the mountain.
the foot of a mountain(= the bottom of a mountain )we’ll take the car to the foot of the mountain and walk from there.
the side of a mountainthe path wound up the side of the mountain.

children.name: mount x
children.definition: mount(written abbmt)  used in the names of mountains.
examples: mount fuji/ mount everest (don’t say ‘fuji mountain)

children.name: peak b1
children.definition: peak a mountain: đỉnh; chỏm; ngọn núi
examples: mount mckinley is alaska’s highest peak.
it is one of the most difficult peaks to climb.
the highest peakmount mckinley is alaska’s highest peak.

children.name: an area that have a lot of mountains or hills
hilly x
children.definition: hillyhaving a lot of hills: có nhiều đồi
examples: hilly region/area/terrain etc
a hilly area

children.name: highlands x
children.definition: highlandsa mountainous area of a country→ lowlands : vùng cao, cao nguyên
examples: most villages in the highlands are now connected by roads.
forested highlands
highland[attri adj] in or relating to an area with mountains or hills
highland springs

children.name: mountainous x
children.definition: mountainoushaving a lot of mountains: có nhiều núi
examples: the mountainous coast of wales
a mountainous region

children.name: with lots of hills or mountains
hilly x
children.definition: hilly an area of land that is hilly has lots of hills: lồi lõm
examples: the hilly farmlands of new jersey
the vineyards are hilly and difficult to cultivate.

children.name: rolling x
children.definition: rollingrolling hills/fields/farmland etcwith a lot of rounded, not very steep hills and valleys, especially when this looks attractive: “cuồn cuộn”
examples: the castle is set in rolling hills to the north of orvieto.
he stood at the top of the hill, admiring the rolling landscape.

children.name: mountainous x
children.definition: mountainous an area of land that is mountainous has lots of high mountains: chập chùng
examples: the mainland of greece is mountainous and largely infertile.
fog and rain are common in the mountainous regions near the border.

children.name: hillside x
children.definition: hillside the sloping surface of a hill, rather than the level surface at the top of it: sườn đồi

children.name: hilltop x
children.definition: hilltop the top part of a hill, rather than its sloping sides: đỉnh đồi

children.name: ridge x
children.definition: ridge a long narrow area of high ground, especially at the top of a mountain :rặngnúi
examples: i could see a group of climbers high up on a ridge.
we walked along the narrow mountain ridge.
figurativea ridge (= narrow area) of high pressure will bring good weather this afternoon.

children.name: caldera x
children.definition: caldera  a very large circular hollow that remains when the central part of a volcano falls in after an eruption: lòng chảo

children.name: mountainside x
children.definition: mountainside the side or slope of a mountain: sườn núi
examples: can you see those goats high uponthe mountainside?

children.name: mountaintop x
children.definition: mountaintop the top of a mountain : đỉnh núi

children.name: peak b1
children.definition: peak the sharply pointed top of a mountain : đỉnh; chỏm; ngọn núi
examples: snow-cappedmountain peks
jagged peaks
a mountain peakall around are the spectacular mountain peaks of the jungfrau region.
a snowy/snow-capped peakthe snow-capped peaks of the sorondo mountain range provide a dramatic backdrop.
a jagged peak(= with several sharp points )at first all i could see was the hazy black outline of a jagged peak.
a rocky peakthe castle is situated on a rocky peak.
a distant peakthe mist cleared to reveal the distant peaks across the valley.

children.name: summit c1
children.definition: summit the highest point of a mountain: đỉnh, chỏm, chóp, ngọn
examples: on this day in 1784, dr michel paccard and jacques balmatreachedthe summit of mont blanc.
summit of
many people have now reached the summit of mount everest.

children.name: clifftop x
children.definition: clifftop an area of ground at the top of a cliff
examples: we stayed in a marvellous clifftop hotel.

children.name: foothills x
children.definition: foothills a group of smaller hills below a range of high mountains : vùngđồi thấp
examples: the foothills of thepyrenees
the sierra foothills

children.name: hill a2
children.definition: hill an area of land that is higher than the surrounding land: đồi
examples: hills are not as high as mountains.
their house is on a hill overlooking the sea.
a cart was making its way up the hill.
steepshe pushed her bicycle up the steep hill.
rolling/gentle hills(= hills with slopes that are not steep )he loved the green rolling hills of dorset.
a long hillthe bus started going up the long hill into town.
climb a hill(= walk or drive up a hill )she climbed the hill out of the village.
go down a hillit's best to use a low gear when you are going down steep hills.
the top of a hillthe view from the top of the hill was beautiful.
the brow/crest of a hill(= the top part of a hill )a tank appeared over the brow of the hill.
the bottom/foot of a hillthe house was at the bottom of a hill.
a hill townthe hill towns of tuscany
hill country(= a rural area where there are a lot of hills )the rough hill country on the welsh border

children.name: knoll x
children.definition: knoll a small low hill with a rounded top:gò
examples: a grassy knoll

children.name: crag x
children.definition: crag a high rough mass of rock which sticks out from the land around it:vách đá cheo leo
examples: an eagle sailed over the high crags.
craggy[adj]having many crags:lởm chởm đá,
a craggy coastline

children.name: precipice x
children.definition: precipice  a very steep side of a cliff or a mountain:vách đứng
examples: the film opens with a shot of a climber dangling from a precipice.
they were standing on the edge of a precipice.

children.name: range b1
children.definition: range a group of hills or mountainsarranged in a line:dãy (núi, đồi..)
examples: the mountain range that is part of the border between norway and sweden
the pennine range
a land of highmountain rangesand deep valleys
range of mountains/hills
the longest range of hills in the lake district
we could see a low rangeofhills in the distance.

children.name: cliff b1
children.definition: cliff a high area of rock with a very steep side, often on a coast vách đá (nhô ra biển)
examples: keep away from the edge of the cliff - you might fall.
high/lowthe cliffs here are the highest in britain.
steep(= sloping at a high angle )the cliffs were steep and dangerous.
a sheer/vertical cliff(= straight up and down rather than sloping )sheer cliffs defend the island.
a sea cliffthe birds breed mainly on sea cliffs and in sea caves.
a coastal cliffhere the coastal cliffs are low, jutting out into the sea.
a rocky cliffthe forest stops where a rocky cliff falls to a saltwater lagoon.
a craggy/jagged cliff(= with a lot of sharp rocks )this is an area of spectacular gorges and jagged cliffs.
a rugged cliff(= rough and uneven )huge atlantic waves were breaking against the rugged cliffs.
a towering cliff(= very high )the towering cliffs of gibraltar
chalk/limestone/granite cliffswhite chalk cliffs rose up from the sea.
a cliff face(= a steep surface or side of a cliff )some climbers were scrambling up the steep cliff face.
a cliff edgekeep away from the cliff edge.
a cliff topthere was a lovely view from the cliff top.
a cliff ledge(= a flat narrow piece that sticks out from a cliff )some of the goats were even grazing on the cliff ledges.
a cliff pathi followed the cliff path down to the bay.
a cliff walk(= a walk along cliffs )shall we do the cliff walk this morning?
be perched (high) on a cliff(= be situated on a cliff )an 11th century castle is perched high on the cliff.
